awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Perceptual and Mnemonic Functions of the Perirhinal Cortex in Stimulus Representation
awd_abstract_narration:
All animals possess the ability to form memories. In mammals, the hippocampal memory system is a conglomerate of brain structures that function together to support memory formation. In doing so, this memory system associates, or binds together, people, items, and places into what are known as episodic memories. Episodic memories afford species the ability to remember vital information that increases the likelihood of survival, such as securing long-term food sources. In this example, the animal must remember "what" was stored, "where" it was stored, and "when" it was stored to retrieve the food before it spoils and avoid illness in the process. Within the hippocampal memory system, the predominant role of one structure, called the perirhinal cortex, is to supply a representation of "what" information (e.g., what food item was stored). The perirhinal cortex also appears to be involved in complex stimulus representations outside of its role in episodic memory; however, how and under which circumstances the perirhinal cortex is involved in stimulus representation is currently under debate. This project assesses how the perirhinal cortex functions in a perceptual-specific versus a memory-specific manner in its representation of item information. In addition, the project examines whether the role of the perirhinal cortex in stimulus representation involves connections with structures outside of the hippocampal memory system. Results will furnish significant insight into the contributions of the perirhinal cortex to stimulus representation and how it may differ or complement its well-established role in episodic memory within the hippocampal memory system.  All components of the research program provide training opportunities to students at California State University-Sacramento, a minority serving and primarily undergraduate institution. Additionally, outreach events provide students with opportunities to increase STEM-awareness in the community.

Currently, it is debated how the perirhinal cortex may function in stimulus representation, and if this function is independent from its mnemonic role within the hippocampal memory system. This project uses an associative learning paradigm (Pavlovian fear conditioning) in combination with an innovative inactivation method, Designer Receptors Exclusively Activated by Designer Drugs, and cross-lesion techniques to evaluate the functional role of the perirhinal cortex in stimulus representation. Specifically, using the laboratory rat as a model system the project aims to: 1) examine the characteristics of stimuli that require the perirhinal cortex for stimulus representation; 2) determine whether the role of perirhinal cortex in stimulus representation is perceptual, mnemonic or a combination; and 3) determine whether in stimulus representation the perirhinal cortex relies on direct connections with structures outside of the hippocampal memory system.  The research project provides extensive training opportunities to students at California State University-Sacramento, which is a minority serving and primarily undergraduate institution. Further, community outreach, which includes events that expose elementary school girls to science, promote university-wide brain awareness and present research findings to the local community, provide students with opportunities to increase STEM-awareness in the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the funded project were to understand the perceptual and mnemonic functions of the perirhinal cortex in stimulus representation as a structure within the hippocampal memory system. The hippocampal memory system is a conglomerate of brain structures that function together to form memories of our daily experiences, known as episodic memories.  Episodic memories combined information about "what", "where", and "when" into a single memory. The perirhinal cortex is primarily responsible for the representation of "what" information. However, the perirhinal cortex also appears to be involved in complex stimulus representations outside of its role in episodic memory, but how and under which circumstances the perirhinal cortex is involved in stimulus representation is under debate. The funded award had three objectives, to examine the characteristics of stimuli that require the perirhinal cortex for stimulus representation, to determine whether the role of perirhinal cortex in stimulus representation is perceptual, mnemonic or a combination of both, and to determine whether in stimulus representation the perirhinal cortex relies on connections with structures outside of the hippocampal memory system.

Results have found that stimuli that are discontinuous in nature more heavily rely on the perirhinal cortex for stimulus processing. For example, manipulation of perihinal cortex function during extinction learning significantly impaired the fear memory and retreival of the extinction memory to a discontinuous light stimulus. This effect was not consistency observed when a continuous light stimulus was used. Results indicate that likely the function of the perirhinal cortex in stimulus representation of discontinuous stimuli is a combination of perceptual and mnemonic functions. Manipulations of perirhinal function both before and after stimulus processing during the learning phase significantly impacted behavior, suggesting that stimulus representation and stimulus-related memory were affected. Finally, evidence from cross-lesion experiments demonstrated that the perirhinal cortex interacts with task-relevant structures outside of its role in the hippocampal memory system. These connections between the perirhinal cortex and task-relevant structures are necessary for stimulus processing.

The laboratory of the Principal Investigator is one of the few labs examining the role of perirhinal cortex in stimulus respresention during associative fear conditioning and extinction tasks. 

The outcomes of this grant have been broadly shared through educational opportunities to K-12 education and the community. An educational workshop was developed for 7th and 8th-grade girls to learn about neural communication and emotional processing in the brain as a gateway to increase interest in STEM-focused careers. In addition, presentations focused on brain structures supporting emotional learning and memory have been given at community-based workshops in the Sacarmento region. Finally, this research was conducted at a primarily undergraduate and teaching-focused institution. The award supported a mentorship and training program for a diverse student population in neuroscience. Evaluation of the program indicated significant gains in technical skills, exploring science, thinking like a scientist and becoming a scientist. Evaluation of the program also indicated increased likelihood of the students in this mentorship program persuing careers in graduate education in neuroscience.
